Name: Multi-scale evolutionary engineering
Content:
Bioengineering needs an evolutionary toolbox.
We help build it.

Forecasting evolution can allow us to design biotechnology, healthcare, and policy that is more effective and robust.

To do this, we build tools to incorporate evolutionary likelihood into bioengineering across scales, from the molecular to the metapopulation level.

We foster open collaboration, effective communication, and dedicated mentorship. We rethink and experiment with how science operates and how it interacts with society.

MsEE Lab is led by Pablo CÃ¡rdenas R. and will open in the summer of 2026 at the Smith School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering of Cornell University in Ithaca, NY, USA.

Name: Applications
Content: We collaborate with different area experts to apply the tools and design principles of evolutionarily-robust bioengineering on problems ranging across antimalarial discovery, influenza immunity, and therapeutic delivery for cancer and beyond. We look forward to seeing this list grow!

Name: Synthetic biology
Content: In order to measure the impact of engineering interventions on evolution, we need tightly-controlled experimental systems with which to dissect these effects. Synthetic biology allows us to repurpose systems with different biological functions into tools for manipulating evolution in a controlled environment.

Name: Computational models
Content: To evaluate the evolutionary robustness of different strategies in a bottom-up, quantitative, and causal fashion, we develop multi-scale, mechanistic computational models. We inform these models with parameters derived from top-down machine learning and simulation-based inference.
